body: Oh sweet, this bug is finally getting fixed :P
is there a test for this?
@fjy why was this merged without having 2 üëç 's?
Is this a documented bug?
If https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3042/files#r65423881 needs to be addressed otherwise will close the PR

üëé  (please hold off on merging a bit) I'd like to see more information on the intended use case.

Here are the things I'm seeing as a result of this PR:
- There is both serviceName and NodeTypeConfig. the NodeTypeConfig is currently only used in `StorageNodeModule` for reporting server metadata. You are expanding its capacity here and I'm not sure that is the best way to do things
- It is entirely possible for an extension to inject a string value from a property. If this is for reporting purposes AND `serviceName` is insufficient, can you explain why having a customizable property string is also insufficient?

And as mentioned earlier, there hasn't been a good delineation of services vs capacities/modules. Different CLIs have a collection of capacities which are grouped together into the service. CLIs are extensible and custom extensions can have various implementations, and even different combinations of properties greatly change the behavior of the service (we have both fast and slow brokers for example, that behave very differently even though they are both CliBroker).
@drcrallen i am not use, if you are asking if there is an existing documentation or if i have to add this documentation ?
@b-slim I mean @fjy referred to something finally getting fixed, and I was curious if this was a something that already had an issue.

For example, does the assumption about binding `NodeTypeConfig` in the CLI still make sense and is required when there are hierarchical brokers that vary in how their query runner is bound rather than the CLI itself, or when there is are a bunch of spark tasks which do intermediate merging and then merge the final results in a driver? Or if there is an extension with [custom CLI impls](https://github.com/metamx/druid/tree/taskTier/extensions-core/tasktier/src/main/java/io/druid/cli)? What should the binding look like there?
@b-slim can you add tests for this?
@drcrallen this bug has been around from a time where I think I was the only person in the world working on Druid
Related: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2024

@pjain1 this looks like a bigger problem, it actually breaks the coordinator ui entirely if a whitelist has been set through the REST API. Looks like this was broken in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1990 when adding that field. @himanshug can you look into that?

@sandepudi I'm not sure how queries have anything to do with HDFS? When you're using `gs://` and aren't using hadoop for indexing you basically only need one node to "proxy" the segment requests.

It shouldn't be too hard to get this pull request working with the latest changes. But the reason we didn't choose for this route is that it isn't tested as well as the HDFS code. If you want I can bring the pull request up to date and see if there is interest in merging?

@drewdahlke could you post more of the overlord logs? I don't see any activity from the supervisor in those logs so it's hard to decipher what's going on. The expected behavior is that a failed task should be replaced with another task by the supervisor shortly after the failure, and that task should start reading from where the previous task started. If you can post the supervisor spec there might be some hints in there as well.

Sure thing

[overlord.txt](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/files/296014/overlord.txt)
[spec.txt](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/files/296013/spec.txt)

@drcrallen sounds good but we should remember to backport
@erikdubbelboer do you mind backporting this PR to the 0.9.1 branch?

@drewdahlke thanks - the last lines of the log seems to indicate that there are 4 "active" tasks which matches your spec (2 taskCount \* 2 replicas) so the supervisor's done its job there; active here means that they are either pending start or are running on a worker, but the startTime being unavailable probably means that they are sitting in pending state and haven't been picked up by a middle manager (probably because your middle manager crashed). Does that seem to match what's happening, i.e. if you check your overlord console do you see 4 tasks sitting around waiting to start? If so, do you have worker capacity available (under the Remote Workers section of the console)?

Also is the MM exception happening fairly consistently or was it a one-off failure?
@l15k4 You might be running against the quickstart config in `conf-quickstart` rather than the clustered config in `conf`, could you double-check that?

@himanshug no he is not.

At some point we will rebuild the coordinator UI but for the time being we need to fix this
@himanshug the problem is with #1990 not the UI
If I had to guess, the UI probably doesn't support sending/receiving json arrays, which it would have to in order to deal with killDataSourceWhitelist.
@gianm that makes sense
Ou my, sorry guys. After triple checking everything, it turns out that I really supplied quickstart conf instead of the modified one, sorry !!!
@b-slim if this is for 0.9.1 it needs a backport

Although, IMO a more robust fix would be to use a counter that increments each time the overlord gains leadership such that two leadership cycles do not interfere with each other.
üëç

@drcrallen

Thanks for the feedback, to elaborate on the use case, the nodeType would be used to provide necessary context for events in a metrics collection/analysis UI (since the meaning of a metric event depends on the type of node it came from).

serviceName can be overridden by users with their own naming conventions, so it's not suitable for this purpose.

A customizable property string would work but would require the user to manage type configuration for all their nodes, which I feel is more error-prone than a fixed property.

I'll close this PR, since the default serviceName is accessible to the emitter extension and that suffices for my purposes without needing this additional NodeTypeConfig setup.

added this note to QTL:
- Static configuration via the druid.query.extraction.namespace.lookups property is no longer supported. Instead, lookups can be configured at runtime via [dynamic configuration](http://druid.io/docs/0.9.1-rc1/querying/lookups.html#dynamic-configuration).
@b-slim updated
üëç
@drcrallen does the diff look reasonable?

@drcrallen üëç  in that this is an improvement, although IMO the clearest way to explain this stuff would be for the examples to all use lookup extractors that really exist (like "map" and "cachedNamespace"). If the examples do not use cachedNamespace then ideally there should be a link to the extension doc near the examples where those kinds of lookups can be used (sorta like how the deep storage page links to s3/hdfs extensions)

I think all the framework all examples with a single lookup should use `map` and and the example with many lookups should have a `map`, `cachedNamespace`, and a made up lookup.

I think it is ok to show a cachedNamespace example in the core docs just like it is ok to have a made up example.
@gianm moved examples to `map`

actually deserialization of json array works fine, so if someone updated killDataSourceWhitelist using direct POST request and then viewing the config in the coordinator UI, it shows up as a comma separated list of dataSources fine.
however, if someone now wants to save updated config via the ui, then that does not work because request sent does not have a json array in killDataSourceWhitelist but a string.
Can you add tests for this also?

@gianm `firstCacheTimeout` is a property of the namespace factory that should help mitigate this. Default is 60,000 (1 minute). Was that property set in this offending case?

Yeah, bouncing the overlord gets things back in gear. I noticed when it was in a bad state all the active tasks had empty offsets, null startTime, null remainingSeconds. Attaching the before/after payloads

I wonder if there's an edge case where loosing a peon to an IOException from S3 throws off the overlord's state.
@drcrallen it is not clear what is exactly this PR is Solving can you please explain more what it going on ?

@drewdahlke cool, glad you were able to get things going again. I tried to reproduce it by forcing an exception at that point in the code but the MM and overlord were able to recover so I'm not exactly sure what sequence of events happened to get your overlord into that state. If you happen to see it again and can write up a fairly reliable repro for it, that would be super helpful. 

In the meantime, I noticed that in your spec you had specified a replication factor of 2 but were only running one middle manager. Just wanted to make sure it was clear that replication works by enforcing that replica tasks run on separate middle managers so that ingestion won't be interrupted by the failure of an MM; hence for 2 replicas, you'll want to run at least 2 MMs (otherwise they'll just sit in pending and be killed when the running one succeeds without doing any work).
